video.title: Calculus 1 - Full College Course
video.description:
Learn Calculus 1 in this full college course.

This course was created by Dr. Linda Green, a lecturer at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Check out her YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkyLJh6hQS1TlhUZxOMjTFw

This course combines two courses taught by Dr. Green. She teaches both Calculus 1 and a Calculus 1 Corequisite course, designed to be taken at the same time. In this video, the lectures from the Corquisite course, which review important Algebra and Trigonometry concepts, have been interspersed with the Calculus 1 lectures at the places suggested by Dr. Green.

⭐️ Prerequisites ⭐️
🎥 Algebra: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LwCRRUa8yTU
🎥 Precalculus: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eI4an8aSsgw

⭐️ Lecture Notes ⭐️
🔗 Calculus 1 Corequisite Notes: http://lindagreen.web.unc.edu/files/2020/08/courseNotes_math231L_2020Fall.pdf
🔗 Calculus 1 Notes: http://lindagreen.web.unc.edu/files/2019/12/courseNotes_m231_2018_S.pdf

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

topLevelComment.author: Bianca
topLevelComment.text: During my high school years I had the worst math professor who constantly screamed at us, used very rude manners and contributed to making me anxious and terrified of math to the point I was convinced I was a completely lost cause. This was then followed by a 1st year of uni Analysis I professor who started off by announcing "I am going to be the primary obstacle between you and graduating". I was completely lost and discouraged, dropped out and proceeded to obtain a degree in an unrelated field. Then my passion for the sciences resurfaced, and I joined a new degree and am about to start with Analysis II. This video is helping me pick up all the scattered calculus I topics I did throughout the years, and I can't express enough gratitude to this teacher and all the teachers in online communities who teach math in a soothing and clear way, avoiding  screaming or intimidations. Hopefully I will do even more math in the future!

topLevelComment.author: Whosoever
topLevelComment.text: In high school I got Ds and Cs in math.  In College I got an A in Calculus.  The difference was an encouraging professor and many hours laboring in the math lab.  I was determined to understand it.  Your determination determines your future.  I became a CPA using algebra everyday.  I suppose I should have become a higher paid actuary, but I was not as determined to master statistics. 😊. Good luck to all.  The man who invented the jet engine was able to do it because of his determination not because he was deemed smart.  The world is your oyster if you dive into the ocean.

topLevelComment.text:
3:30:09 
Can someone explain to me why we plugged in (2 + h) for one of the x's, but we plugged in just 2 for a different x? why not put all 3 x variables at (2 + h), or all 3 x variables at just 2?

replies.author: thePRUH!!!!
replies.text: @Dogglet Pug My pleasure

replies.author: Dogglet Pug
replies.text: @thePRUH!!!! Much appreciated my friend! You are a life saver

replies.author: thePRUH!!!!
replies.text:
This might be too late but the definition of a limit is lim h->0 f(x+h) - f(x) / h, where this formula is basically approaching f(x) incrementally from some h numbers away. We'll use the example in the video.

f(x) = x^3 - 3x, x = 2

We want to know what's going on with the change of y when x = 2. To approach x = 2, we can incrementally approach it by some random variable, and this is what h is. The variable h is just a constant we're adding to x in order to figure out the change at y. The limit adds to the meaning, where if we, for any h, start decreasing or increasing h so that it comes closer to 0, we will eventually find what f'(2) is.

f'(2) = f(2+h) -- f(2) / h

Here, you just plug in whatever variable x the function is at. In this case, 2+h and h, where f(2+h) would be:

f(2+h) = (2+h)^3 - 3(2+h)

and f(2) would just be:
f(2) = (2)^3 - 3*(2)

I apologise but I'm too lazy to foil the (2+h)^3. Essentially, your answer in the end should be:

f'(2) = 3*(2)^2 - 3 = 9

topLevelComment.author: Missskaush
topLevelComment.text: Can someone explain how she factors at 51:38? I'm completely lost...

replies.author: thePRUH!!!!
replies.text:
x * sqrt(x+3) + 2x - sqrt(x+3) - 2
x * sqrt(x+3) - sqrt(x+3) + 2x -2
[sqrt(x+3) * (x - 1)] + 2 * (x - 1)

Basically find which variables are the same, divide the numbers that have the same variables by that variable, group them together in a bracket, and multiply it with the variable you just took out. A simple way to look at it is:

x * sqrt(x+3) + 2x - sqrt(x+3) - 2

Suppose, 
sqrt(x+3) = a
2 = b

We'd have:

x * a + b * x - a - b
ax + bx - a - b
ax - a + bx - b
a * (x - 1) + b * (x - 1)

ax - a = a (x - 1) because ax/a is just x and a/a is 1. Same goes for the second bit.

topLevelComment.author: Tim Rubin Halcomb
topLevelComment.text: The first year of Calculus is actually quite easy if you have a great background in the other areas of mathematics, BUT, Multivariate Calculus is not going to be easy for anyone! For example, utilize the Lagrange Method to solve for peaks and toughs of a function and show me how it can be used to maximize profits. Explain how surface integrals are derived and give me an illustrative example of how projections can be used to map functions from one coordinate system into the other. Etc. Greens, Gauss, Maxwell, and a lot of others took calculus into the next playing field. Line integrals, for example, aren't really limited to lines, they should be referred to as curve integrals, and vector analysis will blow your mind. lol. I will admit that the many different strategies for integrating can get very involved. Are you familiar with Simpson's rule to approximate areas used parabolic approximations. Maybe the first part of calculus can be learned in 12 hours, but even with that, you're just scratching the surface. Are familiar with the Taylor, McClaurin Series? Calculus in 12 hours? Well, no! Sorry!

topLevelComment.author: E H
topLevelComment.text:
Warning to all who will take calculus 1 this fall: your first topic will probably be "epsilon-delta proofs." Epsilon-delta proofs are an advanced topic that has a tendency to scare students out of STEM in the first week (literally). 

During that section of class, do your best to understand the content, but all you really need to do (at that point) is memorize. The rest of the class is not as abstract as that section, so it gets easier. 

In a couple of years, if you are a math major, you might take an upper-division Real Analysis class that covers epsilon-delta proofs. Until then, don't lose sleep over them.

topLevelComment.author: Bjorn Bleta
topLevelComment.text: I mean this from the bottom of my heart: THANK YOU SO MUCH! YOU ARE A ONE OF A KIND HUMAN BEING! I am a senior with a Neuroscience major and this is the last course that is required in my degree plan to graduate and you're the reason I can understand calculus again. I was in a really big motor vehicle accident a few years ago, which left me with TBI and other neurocognitive deficiencies. Before my accident, I loved calculus and I was really good at this. After the accident, it was like my slate was wiped completely clean (regarding mathematics and languages; I lost the ability to speak 4 languages). I have attempted to take integral calculus since my FRESHMAN year in college and I have dropped the course a total of 3 times because I literally could not do it. I didn't know where to begin. I didn't know the extent of the amnesia and it is incredibly devastating and frustrating to look at a subject you used to love and did really well in, and now, I can barely...BARELY remember trig, much less integral calc. But you are truly a godsend, I can't thank you enough. I literally cried when I found this video because the only thing standing between me and a Neuroscience B.S. degree, was this course; I genuinely thought I was going to fail. So thank you for this; you have blessed many lives

topLevelComment.author: Palme d'Ot Comme
topLevelComment.text: 5:50:24 This is not the first time in the video, but when taking the limit as theta approaches 0 of theta/sin(theta) it's just stated that this is the same thing as the limit as theta approaches 0 of sin(theta)/theta. What is the explanation for this? By the limit rules introduced this looks incorrect. Thank you to anyone who might see this and can help!

replies.author: Carl Hansen
replies.text:
To prove this with limit rules, it requires a famous theorem called the squeeze theorem.

The idea is that we bound the function y=theta between y=sin(theta), and y=tan(theta), which you can prove geometrically.  Since sin(theta) approaches tan(theta) for small values of theta as theta approaches zero, this also shows that sine(theta) = theta = tan(theta) for this limit.

replies.author: Black’sPlay
replies.text: @Tanmay Mantri Every polynomial function is continuous, it's rule. If you don't know what polynomial function is, (which I think you do) then the definition is"A polynomial function is a function that involves only non-negative integer powers or only positive integer exponents of a variable". Therefore for example f(x)=3x^5+x^2+7 is continuous because it is polymonial. But function like 5x^(-1)+5 is not because exponent is negative. Also continuous function cannot have ÷ like 2÷x^3 because we can write this as 2×x^(-3) and therfore it has negative exponent, is not a polynomial and not continuous.

replies.author: Tanmay Mantri
replies.text: @Black’sPlay how do we know that the function is continuous, without drawing the graph? In the video, i feel we have assumed it to be continuous.

replies.author: Black’sPlay
replies.text: Because function 5x^4-3x^3-12x+7 is itself countinuous. It does not have any division or anything that would make it non continuous.

replies.author: La villina
replies.text:
3x+6
You have something in common which is 3, you may ask why we’ll it’s because in the numerator 
3=3x1
6=3x2
The common between them is 3
You take 3(x+2)

Now in the denominator 
x2 + 4x + 4
It’s an equation which is called ax2 + bx + c
If you can’t calculate it, just do it on your calculator 
You will get x1=2 / x2=2
You add them in the denominator 
(x+2)(x+2)

That’s how you get it, hope that helps

replies.author: Negoita Mihai
replies.text: if p(x) is a function(meaning it has only one y value for every x you plug into the function), then if you find two x values for which y is negative and then positive, it must have an value x in between that interval for which y=0 (y is also p(x)), we call a real root an y result which intersects the x axis, so any y that is 0 is called a real root. Real root comes from the fact that real numbers can only be imagined in an interval(one dimension), which is in our choice the Ox axis, for example if an function had only values y of 0, it would be an straight line that oversteps the x axis, in which case all real roots of the function are all real numbers :). Such a function is defined as y=0, a pretty simple and intuitive function which represents a horizontal line which oversteps the x axis.

topLevelComment.author: BTW
topLevelComment.text:
Can someone please help me with this using derivatives to simplify and solve for x? I would appreciate any help. Thanks.

v = velocity
a = acceleration
t = time
x = displacement

v = dx/dt
a = dv/dt

a = d(dx/dt)/dt

replies.author: Carl Hansen
replies.text:
I don't understand what you are trying to solve for.  That's just the definitions of the kinematic quantities, and you end up with a derivative of a derivative to relate a to x.  We commonly indicate this as a = d^2 x/dt^2.

If you know a, and know t, and are trying to find x, you have to integrate once to find velocity, and integrate again to find displacement.  You need to keep track of your constants of integration, and at the end of the problem, you plug in initial conditions to solve for these constants.

replies.author: The Russian Bullfrog
replies.text: @Surya H R Hey so I am not a math major in college so take what I say with a grain of salt, but I am a cs major which requires a lot of math. Personally I don't know where you stand in terms of experience but I expect you are a beginner on account of you saying that you just took a intro to statistics course. Fortunately no matter where you are in terms of experience there is great resources to learn anything from simple algebra to multivariable calculus online. Organic chemistry tutor, Kahn academy, etc. They are all great resources, and there are many more out there. You should use these before going into research, as they will help you to learn new things or even review old things. Math is constantly building upon itself, if there is a weak foundation than it will be much harder to build upon this information. Personally I enjoy math, I see it as almost a puzzle. I can't tell you if you should go through the course or not, but I can tell you what kind of person is needed for math. You need to be able to problem solve rather than just memorized. You need to not be afraid to make mistakes and learn from them. It will be hard sometimes but that makes understanding it more satisfying. If you enjoy math, I think you will like it. Math gets more theory based as you go up. It's your call, but understanding math will help you throughout life even if you don't stick with it after. It teaches you more than just numbers, it teaches you problem solving skills that many lack. I hope this could help. Good luck with your research. 👍

topLevelComment.author: TheDirtyBubble
topLevelComment.text: Algebra 2 and Trigonometry contained in a Calculus course for refreshers is pretty nice actually. In college, typically you have to take a pre-Calculus class that is the pre-cursor of Calculus involving systems of functions, trig functions, unit circle, etc. before you take Calculus 1. Also, at the very end of Calculus 1, you are typically exposed to more topics/methods of integration that carries over into Calculus 2.

topLevelComment.author: Corbin Wilson
topLevelComment.text: I want you guys to understand that this isn’t nearly as in-depth as calculus goes. She’s simply showing you the surface of what calc with ultimately be. When you take the course, no matter how many times you’ve seen this video, it will still be harder than this. That being said, calculus is one of those maths you are completely lost in, and this gives you a general understanding of what you’ll learn in that class

replies.author: Corbin Wilson
replies.text: @Pasta Fighter for my calculus class we have been covering 2-3 sections of a chapter a week, so I watch the video to give myself a basic understanding. Then I read the chapter, then I try some of the problems in the book. If I don’t get those, then I look up a more in-depth video about the topic I am having an issue with. I should also say my teacher is very cubano and has a thick accent. He also expects us to have a basic understanding of the topics already. Hence why I put so much work before hand into learning it. He then teaches a more in-depth version, really making sure we are exposed to all the possibilities that may arise from the topic we are covering.

topLevelComment.author: E
topLevelComment.text: Hey, could somebody please explain to me why multiplying by the conjugate works for solving certain limits with radicals? Could we multiply by other things. Why the conjugate

replies.author: Rachel Ruddy
replies.text: Because multiplying by the conjugate allows you to eliminate the radical. e.g. if you have the expression √(x+4) + 5 (just to pick some random numbers), multiplying by the conjugate [√(x+4) - 5] / [√(x+4) - 5] (basically a special form of multiplying by 1) will help you eliminate that radical as you multiply out (note: I am assuming here, for simplicity's sake, that there is only one radical in this rational expression. I am also ignoring the other half of the original fraction where there is no radical). You get  [√(x+4) + 5][√(x+4) - 5] which solves via FOILing to get (√(x+4) * √(x+4) - 5√(x+4) + 5√(x+4) - 25). To simplify step by step: √(x+4) * √(x+4) becomes just (x+4), since you're essentially squaring a square root; the - 5√(x+4)  and + 5√(x+4) cancel out and become 0; so you're left with (x + 4) - 25, which is a much simpler expression. Basically, the conjugate creates the simplest FOILing result and makes everything much cleaner. hope this helps!!! sorry its so messy lol

replies.author: Matt Naganidhi
replies.text: @Darío Enrique Mercado Santiago I understand most of it but only because I also do practice questions along with it. I recommend you don't rush through the 12 hours but I think you should at least spend just as long doing practice problems yourself. Discussing the content with someone else (even if it's someone without a background in math) and taking your time to think about what you've learnt by thinking of a situation a certain rule might not apply could also help. I recommend you ask a friend to start watching this video with you but separately at your own pace so you can discuss it with each other. Having a math tutor also helps but is not necessary.

topLevelComment.author: 琥珀
topLevelComment.text:
1. 1:23:25 - algebra mistake, plugging in the 2 makes the denominator 7, not 9.
2. 4:14:17 - there are values of x for which secant is undefined. Because I'm not sure if the equation is still considered an identity by mathematicians- possibly; but I feel like that point should have been addressed regardless.
3. 4:46:52 - sound cuts out for a significant portion of this section (Proof of the Power Rule and Other Derivative Rules) This part has been remade, and you can find it on Dr. Green's channel at https://youtu.be/CBp_222OhkY
4. 5:42:12 - sound cuts out again. This time it's a very straightforward part though. If you paid attention, you should have no trouble following along. The written explanation is enough IMO.
5. 7:07:43 - this section (Justification of the Chain Rule) is a repeat of the second half of the previous section. You can skip ahead to the next one.
6. 7:35:20 - probably obvious, but a little tongue slip here: "more straightforward to take the log of both sides" -> "log" is supposed to be "derivative"
7. 7:51:40 - the "thin black line" looks more gray to me than black. (it's also a wave, and there may have been other instances of a wave being referred to as a line, but that's just me being nitpicky)
7. 9:05:21 - ALGEBRA mistake: 6c^2 = 26, not 24!
8. 9:09:09 - This section is in the wrong place (nein nein nein!) This is actually a duplicate of the last section on the course. There's two parts to the Multiple Value Theorem: MVT for functions and MVT for integrals. The one for integrals is later on. If you reach this point in the video, instead of this section, watch the proof of MVT for functions on Dr. Green's channel: https://youtu.be/L2W-CyRYBB0
9. 11:36:07 - 3/2 not 1/2

Just a few nitpicks for a great course. Kudos to Dr. Linda Green, and I hope this helps someone.

topLevelComment.author: Ángel Paludi
topLevelComment.text:
10:38:34 If we take -9.8 m/s^2 as a constant deceleration (because of Earth's gravity), what happens to the change from where the tomato stopped being at rest and started going up?
Isn't that a positive acceleration we're not taking into account?

replies.author: Carl Hansen
replies.text:
@Ángel Paludi Think of the 9.8 m/s^2 number, more as 9.8 Newtons/kilogram, than 9.8 m/s^2.  Yes, they are identical for obvious reasons.  However, 9.8 N/kg gives you more insight as to what it really is.

It is a force per unit mass, rather than an acceleration.  It is only an acceleration in the special case of free fall.  If other forces are involved, you first add up the forces, and then equate to mass*acceleration.

replies.author: heythatswesley
replies.text: @Ángel Paludi That's alright! ^^; You're very welcome :D

replies.author: Ángel Paludi
replies.text: ​@heythatswesley My one year younger self would've appreciated it more, but thank you anyway 😂🤝

replies.author: heythatswesley
replies.text: Nope. t=0 is defined as when the object leaves your hand. It's at that moment when the object begins to accelerate downward due to gravity, because you've stopped applying force to it and it's in freefall (negating air resistance). Hope this helps!

topLevelComment.text: Just a nit picky comment: 3:36:57, the derivative won't measure the velocity, it will only measure the north south velocity, but moving east and west at any speed will not increase the distance from the house, nor will the derivative give you the velocity of the object.  You can circle the distance from your house, never move closer or farther, and thus the graph would be flat...so the derivative in this case does NOT give you useful information.

Most students don't have a strong algebra & trig foundation so a refresher in precal may be what you actually need (People over hype the amount of trig you actually need for cal 1, a small 1 hour video covering the basics of trig tends to be enough, you rarely move past the first quadrant in calculus 1 anyways, having the identities accessible is more important)

topLevelComment.author: Tayyaba Sadiq
topLevelComment.text: Where is domain and range

replies.author: Nates
replies.text:
On the graph, domain is all the acceptable input(x) values, range is all the output values(y) from your function. 

I.e. 

(this linear function takes in an x and returns a y)

f(x) = x + 1

function(you pass this in -> ×) 
= (x+1) <- this will be the y value that is returned

All possible input values will be infinity for this specific function because you can replace x with any value and you will get a vaild number in return
(in this case the number (x + 1) or in other words, a y value)


In a function f(x) = 1 / x
x can't equal 0 because then the output number will be 1/0 which is an invalid number(the domain for this will be from negative infinity to 0 then from 0 to positive infinity)

Range on the otherhand will be all possible output values(y). For the linear function, the y values will span across infinity aswell 

but you can imagine a quadratic function

 f(×) = x^2
Or f(x) = x * x

you'll never be able to have a negative output value(y) so the range for that would be from 0 to infinity.

replies.author: Nates
replies.text:
It's because the denominator needs to be the same in order to add 

If I did something like
2*3/3*3    +    5/9

This would be valid, but if I factored out the three

2/3    +    5/9

Now I can't add them together cause the denominator isn't the same

topLevelComment.author: radwizard
topLevelComment.text: Mathematics is not a spectator sport. You must do it to learn it. I can recommend Stewart Calculus. You can get the older textbooks with solutions manual very cheap. 7th edition is great. Many Teachers have respect for Stewart Calculus. I hope you do well and achieve your dreams. Not a day goes by in my STEM that I am not using Calculus somewhere. I will be honest, I almost failed out of Physics until I put it on hold and went back and really learned Calculus. Once I had calculus, everything get became easy. Please do not give up on your Dream. Anything worth doing is worth doing well, and often is difficult. Success doesn't come often without many failures first.

topLevelComment.text: Wai is this like a basic course to learn before starting college or is this what they teach in the first year of uni cause we do almost all of this for our A level

replies.author: Dimithriツ
heisvi
replies.text:
@Dimithriツ
Pretty much, I can tell you my curriculum, which should be similar to the US.

First semester:

Part I: Pre-calculus
- Sets: set operations, set relations

- Numbers and Inequalities:  hierarchy of counting, order and inequalities, intervals

-Quantifiers and Logic: Predicate, and/or/not, implications, universal and existential quantifiers, relation to sets

-Definitions, Theorems and Proofs: Methods of proof, contradiction, common fallacies

- Functions I: Parts of a function, visualizing a function, operations on functions, symmetries, roots, piecewise functions, properties of functions

- Polynomials: powers, definition, binomial theorem, factoring, completing the square, roots, polynomial division, partial fractions, inequalities

-Functions II: scaling effects, implicit functions, injective functions, inverse functions, cardinality

-Absolute Values: the absolute value, relation to intervals, algebra with inequalities

-Trigonometry: degrees vs radians, trigonometric functions, between circles and triangles, properties, inverse trigonometric functions,  useful identities

-Exponents and logarithms: multiplying real numbers, the exponential function, logarithms

-Geometry: lines in the plane, conic sections, area and volume

-Rational and reals: the construction of the reals, suprema and infima, density of the rationals

Part 2: Limits
-Informal limits
-Rigorous limit (epsilon delta)
-Limit toolbox (uniqueness and locality, limit laws, squeeze theorem)
-Continuity
-Value theorems (intermediate/extreme)

Part 3: Derivatives
-Derivatives: intuitions and definition, geometry of the derivative, failures of differentiability
-Derivatives 2: Alternative definitions, higher order derivatives, first order results
-Powers and Products: power rule and polynomials, products and quotients
-Trigonometric and Exponential Derivatives: sine and cosine, exponential derivatives, hyperbolic functions
-Chain Rule
-Inverse Function Theorem
-Implicit Differentiation

Part 4: Applications of Derivatives
-Maxima and Minima
-Mean Value Theorem
-L'Hopital's Rule
-Related Rates
-Word Problems and Optimization
-Curve Sketching
-Polynomial Approximations
-Derivatives IRL


I'll put second semester stuff in a separate comment when I have the time.
